conclusion: Determine the condition that F1 must satisfy for the block to start moving upward by analyzing the forces acting on the block and the plank.
The block is subject to gravity mg, the normal force N from the plank, the frictional force f opposing the motion, and the applied forces F1 (horizontal) and F2 (vertical).
The maximum static friction is given by fs = μN, and the kinetic friction is also fk = μN.
For the block to move upward, the vertical forces must satisfy F2 = mg + f.
The horizontal forces must satisfy F1 = N.
The normal force N is due to the horizontal force F1, so N = F1.
The frictional force f is f = μN = μF1.
For the block to move upward, F2 = mg + μF1.
The plank will start to move when the frictional force f is sufficient to overcome the gravitational force on the plank.
The frictional force must be at least equal to the weight of the plank, so μF1 ≥ Mg.
Substitute values: Given M = 0.40 kg, g = 10 m/s², and μ = 0.20, then 0.20 F1 ≥ 0.40 × 10.
The condition that F1 must satisfy for the plank to start moving upward is F1 ≥ 20 N.
